skill.name: architecture-decision-record
skill.description: Use this skill when documenting significant architectural decisions. Provides ADR templates following the Nygard format with sections for context, decision, consequences, and alternatives. Helps teams maintain architectural memory and rationale for backend systems, API designs, database choices, and infrastructure decisions.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown templates and guidance. No executable code, scripts, network operations, or file system access capabilities. The content provides ADR best practices, templates, and examples without any security concerns.

content.value_statement: Teams struggle to remember why decisions were made, leading to repeated debates and rework. This skill provides templates and examples for creating Architecture Decision Records that capture context, alternatives, and trade-offs so teams maintain architectural memory for future reference.
actual_capabilities: Generate ADR documents using Nygard format templates
Document decision context, alternatives, and trade-offs
Create YAML frontmatter for ADR metadata management
Follow review checklists for ADR quality assurance
Model real-world examples of ADRs for common scenarios
Track ADR status lifecycle from proposed to deprecated
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files automatically
Does not integrate with version control systems
Does not generate diagrams or visual artifacts
Does not enforce ADR compliance in workflows

use_cases.title: Document system architecture
use_cases.description: Record major architectural choices with full context for team reference and stakeholder alignment

use_cases.title: Establish technical standards
use_cases.description: Create records of technology selection decisions including database, framework, and infrastructure choices

use_cases.title: Capture decision rationale
use_cases.description: Document why certain approaches were chosen so future team members understand the reasoning

prompt_templates.title: Database Selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR to document our database selection decision between PostgreSQL, MongoDB, and DynamoDB. Include the context of our microservices architecture, requirements for ACID compliance, and comparison of trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: API Versioning
prompt_templates.prompt: Document our API versioning strategy decision. Compare URL path versioning versus header-based versioning versus query parameter versioning. Explain why we chose URL path versioning.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Migration
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR for migrating from a monolith to microservices. Include the strangler fig pattern approach, phase-by-phase implementation plan, and honest assessment of consequences.

prompt_templates.title: Technology Stack
prompt_templates.prompt: Document our technology stack selection for a new backend service. Cover programming language, framework, database, and deployment infrastructure choices with clear rationale for each decision.

output_examples.input: Create an ADR for choosing PostgreSQL as our primary database
output: ADR will include: Status (Accepted), Context with requirements and constraints, Decision section with specific technology choices, Consequences (positive, negative, neutral), Alternatives considered (MySQL 8.0, MongoDB, DynamoDB) with pros/cons and rejection rationale, References to documentation and related ADRs

best_practices: Write ADRs in present tense as historical records that capture decisions at the moment they were made
Document at least two alternatives with honest pros and cons to demonstrate thorough evaluation
Keep ADRs immutable after acceptance - create new ADRs to supersede rather than editing existing ones
anti_patterns: Using vague language like "we might consider using" instead of clear decisions like "we will adopt"
Only listing positive consequences without acknowledging costs, risks, and trade-offs honestly
Skipping alternatives or presenting only obviously inferior options as strawmen

faq.question: What is the difference between this and a design document?
faq.answer: ADRs focus specifically on the why behind decisions, not implementation details. They capture trade-offs and alternatives considered.

faq.question: How many ADRs should a project have?
faq.answer: Only create ADRs for significant decisions that affect multiple components, require team alignment, or involve trade-offs.

faq.question: Can ADRs be integrated with my codebase?
faq.answer: Store ADRs in /docs/adr/ or /architecture/decisions/ alongside code. Use the YAML frontmatter for tooling integration.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only generates documentation templates. No data is sent anywhere or stored externally.

faq.question: Why should I document alternatives I rejected?
faq.answer: Documenting alternatives prevents repeated debates. Future team members can understand why certain approaches were considered and rejected.

faq.question: How does this compare to ADRs in other tools?
faq.answer: This skill provides the Nygard format templates and examples. Integration with specific tools depends on your workflow and version control setup.
